title: 113_hr3464
content: The Act titled "Commercial Vessel Discharges Reform Act of 2013" allows for discharges incidental to the normal operation of covered vessels. The Commercial Vessel Discharges Reform Act of 2013 exempts covered vessels from needing a permit for discharges incidental to their normal operation. Best management practices are outlined for these vessels. The Commercial Vessel Discharges Reform Act of 2013 exempts covered vessels from permit requirements for discharges incidental to their normal operation, defining covered vessels as watercraft engaged in commercial service under 79 feet in length or fishing vessels regardless of length. The term 'discharge incidental to the normal operation of a covered vessel' includes various types of discharges into navigable waters from a covered vessel. Various types of discharges from a covered vessel include protection, controllable pitch propeller and thruster hydraulic fluid, distillation and reverse osmosis brine, elevator pit effluent, firemain system effluent, freshwater layup effluent, gas turbine wash water, motor gasoline and compensating effluent, refrigeration and air condensate effluent, seawater pumping biofouling prevention substances, boat engine wet exhaust, and sonar dome effluent. The curr_chunk discusses pollutants associated with marine propulsion systems, shipboard systems, and hull applications on a covered vessel. The curr_chunk discusses the discharge of pollutants from various sources on a covered vessel into navigable waters. The curr_chunk discusses the exclusion of certain discharges from the normal operation of a covered vessel into navigable waters. The curr_chunk excludes discharges from a covered vessel into navigable waters, including garbage, incinerator ash, oil, hazardous substances, and sewage. It also covers emissions of air pollutants from vessel operations. The curr_chunk discusses discharges into navigable waters from a covered vessel operating in a capacity other than transportation. The Administrator, in consultation with the Coast Guard, determines discharges subject to best management practices. The Administrator, in consultation with the Coast Guard, determines discharges subject to best management practices to mitigate adverse impacts on US waters. The determinations will be promulgated in accordance with section 553 of title 5, United States Code, considering the nature of the discharge, environmental effects, and effectiveness of the best practices. The Administrator, in consultation with the Coast Guard, considers various factors when determining best management practices for discharges, including effectiveness, practicability, impact on vessel operation, legal requirements, international standards, and economic costs. The timing of initial determinations is also specified. The Administrator, in consultation with the Coast Guard, makes initial determinations under subparagraph (A) within 1 year of enactment and reviews them every 5 years thereafter. The Secretary of the department operating the Coast Guard will regulate the use of best management practices for discharges. The Secretary will regulate the use of best management practices for discharges incidental to vessel operations, based on determinations made by the Administrator. Regulations will be promulgated considering vessel classes, types, and sizes, as well as distinguishing between new and existing vessels. The regulations will distinguish between new and existing vessels and provide waivers as needed. This subsection does not affect the application of section 311 to covered vessels. After the regulations are in effect, covered vessels cannot operate or discharge any incidental discharge. Covered vessels must not operate or discharge any incidental discharge into navigable waters if they are not using best management practices meeting standards established under this subsection.
